awd_titl_txt: Supporting the Development of Model-based Reasoning
awd_abstract_narration: The project will test a learning progression for modeling that spans the elementary and middle grades.  Modeling instruction will be organized around concepts in life sciences that cumulate to a strong conceptual understanding of micro and macro evolution.  The work will take place in two districts with underserved children.  A curriculum strand will be created, assessments developed and a longitudinal research study conducted.  The project also includes an extensive professional development model and accompanying dissemination strategy.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Modeling is the practice that most characterizes knowledge production in science. Understanding big ideas in science—like evolutionary theory—means understanding the models that instantiate them. Yet, little is known about how modeling practices develop over a student’s years of schooling, and even less is known about development of the specific models that are foundational for understanding a scientific theory like evolution. Working with professional biologists and ecologists, we identified the organizing concepts of variability, ecosystems, and change (of both individuals and populations) as foundational to understanding evolution from a modeling perspective. Then we studied development and changes in students’ thinking about these ideas as they spent years in instructional contexts that explicitly attended to fostering and learning developmental change in these ideas.

Our first task was helping teachers build and sustain such an instructional context. To do so, we worked intensively in two districts, both with high populations of underserved students (approximately 4 dozen teachers and 1100 students participated). One was a relatively high capacity district with a bilingual school developed to serve Mexican American English Language Learning students. The other was a district struggling to stay off its state’s NCLB watch list. It had a high population of African American, Kurdish, and Mexican immigrant children. We developed, implemented, and investigated an intensive professional development model that entailed face-to-face monthly meetings, week-long summer institutes, and regular email contact. The focus of the teacher workgroups was on developing ways to support the development of student learning across grades and to document their findings, both about student thinking and about effective forms of pedagogy.

            Because models must be accountable to data, we collaborated with Dr. Clifford Konold at the University of Massachusetts/Amherst to make adaptations to his widely used TinkerPlots™, a child-appropriate data analysis tool. These adaptations now support investigations of chance and sampling, modeling, and new representational features. The BEAR Center at the University of California/Berkeley worked with us on early versions of an assessment system. To begin to move these ideas into wider use, we worked with the National Sciences Resource Center to incorporate ideas about modeling, data, and representation into one of their Science and Technology for Children curriculum units. The unit was subsequently tested with six Pittsburgh middle school science teachers.

            Much of the pedagogy in the two research sites was organized around long-term field investigations of local ecologies, including a restored prairie, the school forest, several nearby retention ponds, and in one case, the school’s back yard as it remained undisturbed and was allowed to return to what children referred to as its “wild” state. In the context of their investigations, students posed and investigated their own questions in research teams. These included questions about succession; relations between and among biotic and abiotic components of environments; life cycle and seasonal change, both between and among organisms; aquatic and terrestrial animal behavior; sustainability (of aquatic systems); and many others. The instruction emphasized modeling, representation, and data; in most cases, students supplemented their field studies with models in their classrooms that permitted more direct manipulation and monitoring of the systems under investigation. Instruction was designed to support the development of sophistication in students’ representational and modeling practices, along with their conceptual growth. The project published findings about the development of modeling, as well as the foundational biological themes of change, variability, and ecosystem thinking.  The most compact summary of findings is four “construct maps” that briefly characterize and illustrate typical ways of thinking repeatedly observed by students and organized roughly by sophistication –from novice or very young students on one end of the continuum to relatively sophisticated thinkers, on the other (and anywhere from 6 to 8 levels in between). We regard these construct maps as general guides or models, not as strict developmental stages, because the thinking of any particular student tends to vary with task difficulty. They do, however, provide teachers with a general sense of what is typical and also provide a vision of next forms of thinking that would be profitable to support among a group of students. Moreover, they emphasize students’ resources for learning, not their conceptual deficits.

Over the course of the project, we also studied changes in teachers’ beliefs and practices about teaching mathematics and science, via interview methods, direct observation of classroom teaching, and examination of artifacts presented by teachers in monthly meetings as illustrations of forms of student thinking identified on the construct maps.  In addition, the professional development model is described in the report submitted by our project evaluators, Inverness Research.

            In sum, the intellectual merit of the project lies in its contribution to knowledge about longitudinal change in children’s modeling within foundational concepts of biology. Its broader impact is its focus on and support of better teaching and learning in schools with students who are typically underserved.

 


Last Modified: 09/22/2011
Modified by: Leona Schauble
